<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 120, 377, 144]]<|/det|> # Cambridge IGCSE™ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 193, 200]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 168, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 422, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[619, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 210, 903, 258]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 176, 292]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 903, 292]]<|/det|> 0625/51 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 259, 316]]<|/det|> Paper 5 Practical Test <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[770, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|> May/June 2025 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|> 1 hour 15 minutes <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 400]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 805, 558]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 645, 904, 840]]<|/det|>
For Examiner's Use

Total
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[270, 867, 726, 882]]<|/det|> This document has 12 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 595, 90]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will determine the density of a ball.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 103, 146, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 728, 122]]<|/det|>
Place the ball between the two blocks as seen from above in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 144, 645, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 275, 645, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 275, 645, 275]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 308, 534, 325]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 339, 180, 357]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 339, 917, 373]]<|/det|>
Describe how to use the apparatus in Fig. 1.1 to take two measurements to determine the diameter \(d\) of the ball. You may draw on Fig. 1.1 to help your description.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 432, 918, 450]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 462, 180, 481]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 462, 918, 495]]<|/det|>
Using the blocks as shown in Fig. 1.1, take two measurements to determine the diameter \(d\) of the ball.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 523, 918, 540]]<|/det|>
<form>measurement 1 = .................................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 555, 918, 572]]<|/det|>
<form>measurement 2 = .................................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 572, 918, 590]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 602, 183, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 602, 918, 636]]<|/det|>
Use your measurements to calculate a value for the diameter \(d\) of the ball. Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 725, 918, 743]]<|/det|>
<form>d = .................................................................... $cm$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 725, 920, 744]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 757, 148, 776]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 757, 692, 775]]<|/det|>
Calculate the volume \(V\) of the ball using the equation \(V = 0.52d^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 789, 290, 806]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[552, 912, 918, 930]]<|/det|>
<form>V = .................................................................... $[2]$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 873, 90]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of hot water in a beaker. Refer to Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[203, 100, 791, 275]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 289, 533, 307]]<|/det|> 
Fig. 2.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 322, 146, 339]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 322, 917, 354]]<|/det|>
Use the thermometer to measure the temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the water in the container labelled 'cold water'.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 367, 917, 384]]<|/det|>

\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 397, 146, 416]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 397, 180, 416]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 397, 539, 415]]<|/det|>
V is the total volume of water in beaker A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 428, 557, 446]]<|/det|>
Complete the column headings in Table 2.1.

<|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[305, 492, 692, 753]]<|/det|>

\(V/\)\(\theta /\)
100
120
140
160
180
200


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 750, 920, 768]]<|/det|>
[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 783, 180, 801]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 783, 567, 800]]<|/det|>
• Pour \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 800, 660, 815]]<|/det|>
• Place the thermometer in the hot water in beaker A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 815, 680, 831]]<|/det|>
• Record in Table 2.1 the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 831, 917, 860]]<|/det|>
• Without delay, use the measuring cylinder to add \(20 \text{cm}^3\) of the cold water to the water in beaker A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 860, 450, 876]]<|/det|>
• Stir the water in beaker A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 876, 830, 892]]<|/det|>
• Record in Table 2.1 the temperature of the mixture of hot and cold water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 892, 917, 922]]<|/det|>
• Repeat the procedure, adding \(20 \text{cm}^3\) of cold water each time, until you have a total of \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of water in beaker A.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 923, 920, 941]]<|/det|>
[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 782, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the position of the image in a plane mirror.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 103, 667, 120]]<|/det|>
Use the ray-trace sheet supplied, referring to Fig. 3.1 for guidance.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[289, 131, 707, 549]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 565, 532, 581]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 3.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 597, 146, 615]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 597, 918, 645]]<|/det|>
• Draw a line \(10.0 \text{cm}\) long near the middle of the ray-trace sheet. Label the line \(\mathbf{MR}\). Draw a normal to this line that passes through its centre. Label the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\). Label the point at which \(\mathbf{NL}\) crosses \(\mathbf{MR}\) with the letter \(\mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 644, 918, 675]]<|/det|>
• Draw a line below \(\mathbf{MR}\), \(10.0 \text{cm}\) long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(i = 40^\circ\) to the normal and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 675, 707, 691]]<|/det|>
• Place the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line \(\mathbf{MR}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 691, 918, 723]]<|/det|>
• Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) , on line \(\mathbf{AB}\) at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 723, 918, 736]]<|/det|>
View the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 738, 918, 770]]<|/det|>
Place two pins, \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) , so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_1\) all appear exactly one behind the other. Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 772, 920, 790]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Remove the pins and the mirror. Draw a line through the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line until it meets \(\mathbf{MR}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 117, 918, 149]]<|/det|>
Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between this line and the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\). An acute angle is an angle less than \(90^\circ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 163, 890, 179]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\alpha =\) ............................................................ $^\circ$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 163, 920, 180]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 192, 146, 210]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 192, 583, 210]]<|/det|>
Turn the ray-trace sheet through \(180^{\circ}\). See Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[238, 219, 760, 730]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 740, 533, 757]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 3.2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 770, 918, 804]]<|/det|>
* Draw a line below \(\mathbf{MR}\), 10.0 cm long from \(\mathbf{B}\) at an angle of incidence \(i = 50^\circ\) to the normal and to the left of the normal. Label the end of this line \(\mathbf{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 802, 918, 834]]<|/det|>
* Place pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{CB}\) at a suitable distance apart for this type of ray-trace experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 833, 918, 864]]<|/det|>
* Place the reflecting face of the mirror vertically on the line \(\mathbf{MR}\) with the centre of the mirror at \(\mathbf{B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 864, 890, 880]]<|/det|>
View the images of pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) from the direction indicated by the eye in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 879, 918, 910]]<|/det|>
Place pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_2\) and \(\mathsf{P}_1\) all appear exactly one behind the other. Label the new positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 910, 920, 927]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 845, 90]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the relationship between the diameter and the resistance of wires.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 104, 420, 120]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 135, 400, 150]]<|/det|>
· wires with different diameters

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 151, 547, 166]]<|/det|>
· instrument for measuring the diameter of a wire

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 168, 250, 180]]<|/det|>
· metre ruler

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 184, 240, 195]]<|/det|>
· ammeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 199, 240, 210]]<|/det|>
· voltmeter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 215, 273, 227]]<|/det|>
· power supply.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 243, 702, 258]]<|/det|>
Other apparatus normally found in a school laboratory is also available.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 273, 794, 289]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the diameter of a wire affects its resistance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 298, 917, 336]]<|/det|>
Resistance \(R\) is given by the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\) , where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 351, 902, 367]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to do this investigation. You do **not** need to write about safety precautions.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 383, 224, 397]]<|/det|>
In your plan:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 414, 562, 428]]<|/det|>
· draw a circuit diagram to show the circuit you use

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 431, 494, 444]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how to do the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 446, 484, 459]]<|/det|>
· state **one** key variable to keep constant

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 461, 917, 492]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 494, 598, 507]]<|/det|>
· explain how to use your results to reach a conclusion.
